sub_topic: Prove that every group of order p^3, where p is a prime, is either cyclic or isomorphic to the direct product of a cyclic group of order p and a group of order p^2.
message_1: For a prime number p = 5, prove that every group of order 5^3 is either cyclic or isomorphic to the direct product of a cyclic group of order 5 and a group of order 5^2.
message_2:
Let G be a group of order 5^3 = 125. By the Sylow Theorems, the number of Sylow 5-subgroups of G is congruent to 1 mod 5 and divides 125. The only possibilities are 1 and 25. 

Case 1: There is only one Sylow 5-subgroup of G.
In this case, the unique Sylow 5-subgroup is normal in G. Let P be this Sylow 5-subgroup. Since |P| = 5^3, P is a p-group, and by the Fundamental Theorem of Finite Abelian Groups, P is either a cyclic group of order 125 or isomorphic to the direct product of a cyclic group of order 5 and a group of order 5^2. Since P is normal in G and G has no other proper nontrivial subgroups, G must be isomorphic to P. Thus, G is either cyclic or isomorphic to the direct product of a cyclic group of order 5 and a group of order 5^2.

Case 2: There are 25 Sylow 5-subgroups of G.
Let P be one of these Sylow 5-subgroups. Since |P| = 5^3, P is a p-group, and by the Fundamental Theorem of Finite Abelian Groups, P is either a cyclic group of order 125 or isomorphic to the direct product of a cyclic group of order 5 and a group of order 5^2. 

Now, consider the action of G on the set of its Sylow 5-subgroups by conjugation. This action is transitive, and the stabilizer of P is the normalizer of P in G, denoted N_G(P). By the Orbit-Stabilizer Theorem, |G:N_G(P)| = 25. Since |G| = 125, we have |N_G(P)| = 5. 

Let H be a subgroup of G such that P ⊆ H ⊆ N_G(P). Then, |H| = 5 or |H| = 25. If |H| = 25, then H is a normal subgroup of G, as it has index 5 in G. In this case, G is isomorphic to the direct product of a cyclic group of order 5 and a group of order 5^2, as desired.

If |H| = 5, then H = P, and P is a normal subgroup of G. In this case, G is isomorphic to P, which is either cyclic or isomorphic to the direct product of a cyclic group of order 5 and a group of order 5^2, as desired.

In conclusion, every group of order 5^3 is either cyclic or isomorphic to the direct product of a cyclic group of order 5 and a group of order 5^2.
